newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Sweden debt office head warns on budget optimism.
newsitem.headline: Sweden debt office head warns on budget optimism.

text.p: The head of Sweden's National Debt Office, Thomas Franzen, warned on Wednesday that Sweden should not count on state finances continuing to improve faster than forecast, according to a report in a business daily.
"I have to warn of being too optimistic even if we believe in a surplus," Franzen told Dagens Industri.

His comments came after Prime Minister Goran Persson last week forecast a budget surplus of 10 billion crowns in 1998, pledging this money to municipalities for health and education. This caused interest rates to rise and the crown to weaken.
But Franzen said people should not be too optimistic. He said a surplus is needed for up to 10 years to pay off state debt and to handle future pensions.
Franzen did not directly want to comment on Persson's promise.

"You should not put too much emphasis on short term reactions, but the reaction and the discussion show that the room to act is limited when you have a large debt and a past that we have," Franzen told the newspaper.
But if politicians kept strengthening state finances, there should be room for lower bond yields, he said.
